EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

div.head: THE COPIE OF A LETTER WRITTEN from Ma≈øter C.S. neere Salisbury, to Ma≈øter H. A. at London, concerning the proceeding at Winche≈øter, &c.
div.p:
SIR, I haue receiued a Letter from you by which I perceiue, howe much you de≈øire to be particularly enfourmed of the cau≈øe and maner of the ≈øtay of the late Lord Cobhams. Lord Grayes, and Sir Griffin Marckhams Execution, appointed at Winche≈øter: wherein, although there are many better able to di≈øcour≈øe at large of ≈øuch an Action then my ≈øelfe; yet I conceiue (when you haue peru≈øed this plaine and true Relation, of that
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ

which all men there behelde that day, and many more ≈øince haue heard from per≈øons of be≈øt qualitie and knowledge) you will thanke me more, for ≈øuffering the trueth to ≈øhew it ≈øelfe vnclothed, then if I had laboured to haue deliuered you a Tale well painted with curious words and fine phra≈øes.

You mu≈øt therfore vnder≈øtand, That as ≈øoone as the ArraignmeÃÑts were pa≈ø≈øed at Winche≈øter, his Maie≈øties priuie Coun≈øel (to the number of fourteene or fifteene, of which companie all of them had either bene tryers of the Noble men as their Peeres, or ≈øitten as high Commi≈ø≈øioners vpon the Gentlemen) were called before his Maie≈øtie (in his priuie Chamber) at Wilton, where hee commanded them to deliuer (without re≈øpect to any per≈øon) the true Narration onely, of the order in the Triall of the≈øe per≈øons that had beene condemned by the Law, of the manner of their behauiour at Barre, and of the nature „Äà‚óä„Äâ degree of their offences, as had appeared in euery one of them by their ≈øeuerall an≈øweres.

All which being cleerely and iu≈øtly reported by them, (each ≈øpeaking in the hearing of the re≈øt) his Maie≈øtie (for his part) v≈øed him≈øelfe ≈øo grauely and ≈øo re≈øeruedly in all his ≈øpeeches, as well to them≈øelues at that time, as al≈øo to all other per≈øons after in priuate or publique, as neither any of his priuie Coun≈øell, Nobilitie, or any that attended neere≈øt to his ≈øacred Per≈øon, dur≈øt pre≈øume to mediate for any, or ≈øo much as to enquire what ≈øhould bee the conclu≈øion particularly, of this proceeding.

In the meane time, while the Court was full of varietie of di≈øcour≈øe, ≈øome ≈øpeaking out of probabilitie, others arguing out of de≈øire, what was like to bee the fortune of all, or of any of the≈øe offendours; His Maie≈øtie hauing concluded onely in his owne ≈øecret heart (which is the true oracle of grace and knowledge) in what manner to proceed, (and that without asking coun≈øell of any earthly per≈øon) It plea≈øed him to re≈øolue (betweene God and him≈øelfe) that their Execution ≈øhould be ≈øtayed, euen at the in≈øtant when the Axe ≈øhould be layde to the Trees rootes. For the ≈øecret and orderly carriage whereof, his Maie≈øtie was carefull to preuent all cau≈øe or colour of ≈øu≈øpicion, of that Iudicious, Royall, and vnexpected cour≈øe which followed. And therefore, after the two Prie≈øts were executed on Tue≈øday the 29. of Nouember, and Ma≈øter George Brooke on Munday following, his Maie≈øtie on the ≈øame day, being the fifth of December, ≈øigned three Warants, for the Execution of the late Lord Cobham, L. Gray, and Sir Gryffin Marckham Knight, with particular direction to the Sheriffe, to performe it on Friday after before ten a clocke in the morning.

All the≈øe directions being now become notorious, both by the Writs of execution (which pa≈ø≈øed vnder the great Seale) and by the making readie the Scaffolds at Winchester, His Maie≈øtie very ≈øecretly (as now appeareth by the ≈øequele) drewe him≈øelfe into his Cabinet, on Wedne≈øday before
the day of Execution, and there priuately framed a Warrant written all with his owne hand, to the Sheriffe, by vertue whereof, hee countermaunded all the former directions, alledging the rea≈øons therein mentioned: Of which ≈øeeing no mans Pen can ≈øo well expre≈ø≈øe, as his owne, I ≈øend you the Copie verbatim, as I tooke it out of the Originall, which many read in my Cou≈øen Sir Beniamin Tichbournes hand.

And now to come to the ordering of this bu≈øine≈ø≈øe; among many other circum≈øtances, It is very remarkable, with what di≈øcretion and fore≈øight, that per≈øon was elected, which mu≈øt bee v≈øed in carriage of the Warrant. Fir≈øt his Maie≈øtie re≈øolued, it ≈øhould be a Scotti≈øhman, being thereby like to be free≈øt from particular dependancie vpon any Nobleman, Coun≈øellours, or others, their friends or Allyes. Next hee re≈øolued, to ≈øend a man of no extraordinarie ranke, becau≈øe the ≈øtanders by ≈øhould not ob≈øerue any alteration, nor the delinquents them≈øelues ≈øhould take any apprehen≈øion of ≈øuch a mans being there at that time: This being his Maie≈øties ≈øpeciall de≈øire, that euery one of them (being ≈øeuerally brought vpon the Scaffold) might quietly breath foorth their la≈øt wordes, and true confe≈ø≈øion of his ≈øecrete≈øt con≈øcience. And ≈øo (to be ≈øhort) his Maie≈øtie made choi≈øe of M. Iohn Gibb, a Scotti≈øhman (as afore≈øaid) a man that had neuer dealt with any Coun≈øellor, or other, for ≈øuite or bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, but one that had (within ≈øhort while after
the Kings fir≈øt entrie) beene ≈øent backe into Scotland, from whence he was but now fre≈øhly arriued at Wilton ≈øome fewe dayes before.

This party being by the King approoued for an ancient, tru≈øtie, and ≈øecret ≈øeruant (as a Groome of his Maie≈øties bed-chamber) receiuing the warrant ≈øecretly on Thur≈øday from the Kings owne hand, & telling his fellowes (who would otherwi≈øe haue mi≈ø≈øed him) that he mu≈øt lie that night at Salisburie vpon ≈øome priuate bu≈øine≈ø≈øe of his owne, he rode directly to Winche≈øter, and there, keeping him≈øelfe priuate all night, ro≈øe earely in the morning on Friday, and went ob≈øcurely to the Ca≈øtle greene, where the people flocking in all the morning, as the time drewe neere, hee put him≈øelfe with the throng, clo≈øe by the Scaffold, and there leaned till the Sheriffe brought vp ≈øir Griffin Markham to the place, who was the man appointed fir≈øt to die.

There the ≈øayd Sir Griffin Markham, hauing ended his praier, and made him≈øelfe ready to kneele downe, M. Iohn Gibb finding it fit time, while the Axe was preparing, to giue ≈øome ≈øecret notice of his charge, called to my co≈øin Tichborne the Sheriffe, to ≈øpeake with him, and then deliuered him (priuately) his Maie≈øties warrant, with further directions verbally, how he ≈øhould v≈øe it.

Hereupon the Sheriffe perceiuing fully his Maie≈øties intention, ≈øo warily and di≈øcreetly mar≈øhalled the matter, as hee onely called Sir Griffin Markham vnto him on the Scaffold, and told him,
that he mu≈øt withdraw him≈øelfe into the Hall, to be confronted (before his death) before tho≈øe two Lords, that were to follow him, about ≈øome points that did concerne his Maie≈øties ≈øeruice: and ≈øo carying Markham into the Hall, he left him there, and went vp ha≈øtily for the Lord Gray to the Ca≈øtle, who being likewi≈øe brought vp to the Scaffold, and ≈øuffered to powre out his prayers to God (at great length) and to make his la≈øt confe≈ø≈øion, as he would an≈øwere it vpon his ≈øoule, when he was readie to kneele downe, to receiue the ≈øtroke of death, Ma≈øter Sheriffe cau≈øed him to ≈øtay, and told him that he mu≈øt goe downe for a while into the Hall, where finding Sir Griffin Markham, he willed him to tarry there till he returned.

La≈øt of all, he went for the Lord Cobham, who hauing al≈øo ended his deuotion to God, and making him≈øelfe ready to receiue the ≈øame blow, the Sheriffe finding the time come to publi≈øh the Kings mercie to the world, and to reuea≈øe his my≈øterie, he cau≈øed both the Lord Gray, and Sir Griffin Markham, to be brought backe to the Scaffold, and there, before them all three that were condemned, and in the hearing of all the company, notified his Maie≈øties warrant, by which he was authori≈øed to ≈øtay the execution. Which ≈øtrange and vnde≈øerued Grace and mercie proceeding from a Prince, ≈øo deeply wounded without cau≈øe, or colour of cau≈øe giuen by him≈øelfe towards them in any thing, but meerely contrary (to both the Lords e≈øpecially) bred in the hearts as well of the offenders, as of the
≈øtanders by, ≈øuch ≈øundry pa≈ø≈øions, according to the diuers tempers of their minds, as to tho≈øe that mu≈øt receiue tho≈øe things by report, which others did behold with their eyes, it may rather ≈øeeme to be a relation of a well acted Comedie, then that it was euer po≈ø≈øible for any other man, to contriue a matter (of this nature and con≈øequence) to ≈øerue all purpo≈øes ≈øo aptly, as this was ordered by his Maie≈øties owne and onely directions.

The Lord Cobham (holding his hand to heauen) applauded this incomparable mercie of ≈øo gracious a Soueraigne, aggrauating his owne fault, by comparing it with the Princes clemencie, wi≈øhing confu≈øion to all men aliue, that ≈øhould euer thinke a thought again≈øt ≈øuch a Prince, as neither gaue cau≈øe of offence, nor tooke reuenge of ingratitude.

The Lord Gray, finding in what mea≈øure this rare King had rewarded good for euill, and forborne to make him an example of di≈øcouragement, and terrour to all men that hereafter might attempt to breake the bonds of loyalty, vpon the pa≈ø≈øions of any ambition, beganne to ≈øobbe and weepe for a great while, with mo≈øt deepe contrition, prote≈øting now, that ≈øuch was his zeale and de≈øire to redeeme his fault, by any meanes of ≈øatisfaction, as he could ea≈øily ≈øacrifice his life, to preuent the lo≈ø≈øe of one finger of that royall hand, that had dealt ≈øo mercifully with him, when he lea≈øt looked for it.

Sir Griffin Marckham (≈øtanding like a man a≈øtoni≈øhed) did nothing but admire and pray. The people that were pre≈øent, witne≈ø≈øed by infinite applau≈øe
and ≈øhouting the ioy and comfort, which they tooke in the≈øe wonderfull effects of grace and mercie, from a Prince, whome God had in≈øpired with ≈øo many Royall gifts, for their con≈øeruation, and would con≈øerue for his owne glorie.

The crie being carried out of the Ca≈øtle Gates into the Towne, was not onely ≈øounded with acclamation of all ≈øexes, qualities, and affections, but the true report diuulged ≈øince in all partes, hath bred in the woor≈øt di≈øpo≈øed mindes, ≈øuch remor≈øe of iniquitie, in the be≈øt ≈øuch incouragement to loyaltie, and in tho≈øe that are indifferent, ≈øuch feare to offend, and generally ≈øuch affection to his Maie≈øties Per≈øon: as per≈øwades the world, that Sathan him≈øelfe can neuer ≈øo farre preuaile with any, as to make them lift vp their hearts or hands again≈øt a Prince, from whom they receiue ≈øo true effects of Iu≈øtice, and goodne≈ø≈øe.

To conclude therefore, I haue now done my be≈øt, to ≈øatisfie your de≈øire, though I feele (to my griefe) how ≈øhort I come to my owne wi≈øh, becau≈øe I would haue expre≈ø≈øed to the life (if it had beene po≈ø≈øible) both the matter and the forme of this proceeding; of both which, the wi≈øe≈øt men, that haue ≈øeene and vnder≈øtoode all particular circum≈øtances, are at the ende of their wits, to giue an ab≈øolute cen≈øure, whether of them both de≈øerue greater recommendation, (this being mo≈øt a≈ø≈øured) that there is no Record extant, wherein ≈øo great wi≈øedome and vnder≈øtanding, ≈øo ≈øolid iudgement, ≈øo perfect a re≈øolution, to giue way to no reque≈øt,
or mediation; ≈øo in≈øcrutable a heart, ≈øo Royall and equall a tempered mercie, after ≈øo cleare and publike Iu≈øtice, haue euer concurred ≈øo demon≈øtratiuely as in this late Action, wherein this ble≈ø≈øed King hath not proceeded after the manner of men and of Kings, Sed caelestis Iudicis aeterni
que Regis more, whereof he ≈øhall be mo≈øt a≈ø≈øured to reape the≈øe la≈øting fruites, of being beloued and feared of all men, obeyed with comfort, and ≈øerued with continuall ioy and admiration. And ≈øo forbearing to hold you any longer at this time, I end: From my hou≈øe neere Salisburie, the 15. of December. 1603.

closer.signed: Your Louing Cou≈øin and friend. T. M.

div.head: A TRVE COPIE OF HIS MAIESTIES Warrant written with his owne hand, and directed to the high Sheriffe of Hamp≈øhire for ≈øtay of the execution of the late L. Cobham, L. Gray, and ≈øir Griffin Marckham at Winche≈øter the 9. of December 1603.
div.p:
ALthouch it be true, that all vell gouernid and floori≈øhing Kingdomes and common vealthis, aire establi≈øhid by Iu≈øtice, and that the≈øe tuo Noblemen by birthe, that aire nou vpon the point of Execution, aire for thair trea≈øonable practi≈øes condemnid by the Lawe, and adiudgit voorthy of the execution thaireof, to the exemple
and terror of other is; The one of thaim hauing filthily practi≈øed the ouerthrow of the quhole kingdome, and the other for the ≈øurpri≈øe of our owin Per≈øonne; Yet in regaird that this is the first yeere of our Raigne, in this Kingdome, and that neuer King was ≈øo farre oblei≈øhid to his people, as ve haue bene to this, by our entrie heere vith ≈øo hairtie and generall an applau≈øe of all ≈øorts; Among quhom all the kinne, friendis, and allies of the ≈øaidis condemnid per≈øonnis, vaire as forduart, and duetifull as any other our good Subiectis, as al≈øo that at the very time of thair Arrainement none did more freely & reddily giue thair a≈ø≈øent to thair conuiction, and to deliuer thaim into the handis of Iustice, then ≈øo many of thair neerest kin≈ømen and Allies (as being Peeris) ‚Ä¢ aiere vpon thair Iurie; As likeuai≈øe in regaird that Iustice hath in ≈øome ≈øort gottin cour≈øe alreadie, by the execution of the tuo Priestis, and George Brooke, that vaire the principall plotteris and inti≈øairs of all the re≈øt, to the embracing of the ≈øaidis trea≈øonabill Machinations; Vee thairfore (being re≈øoluid to mixe Clemencie vith Iustice) aire contented, and by the≈øe Pre≈øentis command you, our pre≈øent Sheriffe of Hamp≈øhire, to ≈øuper≈øeide the Execution of the ≈øaidis tuo Noblemen, and to
take thaim backe to thair pri≈øon againe, quhile our further plea≈øure be knowin. And ≈øince ve vill not haue our Lawis to haue respect to per≈øonis, in ≈øpairing the great, and ≈øtrikking the meaner ≈øort; It is our plea≈øure, that the like cour≈øe be al≈øo taken vith Marckham, being ≈øorry from our hairt, that ≈øuch is, not onely the heynous nature of the ≈øaidis coÃÑdemnid per≈øonnis crime, but euen the corruption is ≈øo great of thair naturall dispo≈øition, as the care vee haue for the ≈øafety and quiet of our State, and good Subiectis, vill not permit vs to v≈øe that clemencie to vardis thaim, quhich in our owin naturall inclination, vee micht very ea≈øily be per≈øuadit vnto.
